qas.question: Who made clear the motivations of the filmmakers?
Who encourages watching movies at a theater as making money from the film?
What is restricted to ensure the largest number of people see a movie at the theater?
What is restricted unless the film has a traditional theater release?

answers.text: tax support that a film can receive

qas.question: Who made unclear the motivations of the filmmakers?
Who discourages watching movies at a theater as making money from the film?
What is restricted to ensure the smallest number of people see a movie at the theater?
What is restricted to ensure the largest number of people see a movie at home?

plausible_answers.text: tax support that a film can receive

qas.question: What is unrestricted unless the film has a traditional theater release?

context: In response to Cusumano's perspective, Screen Producers Australia executive director <a0_0><b4_0>Matt Deaner<b4_0/><a0_0/> clarified the motivation of the film industry: "<a1_0><b5_0>Distributors<b5_0/><a1_0/> are usually wanting to encourage cinema-going as part of this process [monetizing through returns] and restrict <b7_0>the <a2_0><b6_0>immediate access to online<b7_0/><b6_0/><a2_0/> so as to encourage the maximum number of people to go to the cinema." Deaner further explained the matter in terms of the Australian film industry, stating: "there are currently restrictions on quantities of <a3_0><b8_0>tax support that a film can receive<b8_0/><a3_0/> unless the film has a traditional cinema release."
